description.narrative: The report being assessed is a four months period report 1 September 2018 to 31 December 2018. During the four months under review the programme was able to achieve results that would normally take long to achieve within a short space of time because, the interventions built on the previous work by implementing partners in the same project area. The use of existing structures also contributed to the success of the programme during the reporting period. A more comprehensive assessment will be done at the end of 2020. The activities in the four months will be included in this 2020 reports. However, during the period under review, right holders assumed their critical oversight and monitoring roles on local authority performance and were able to bring duty bearers to account. This has in some areas contributed to increased uptake and responsiveness of duty bearers to rights holders' service delivery demands. The capacity building component of the programme saw an improved capacity of CSOs partners to form strategic alliances for synergies around common interest issues affecting holders well being. The young people through innovative youth friendly social accountability platforms were able to access strategic information on governance. The youth and women participation in governance issues was visible during the period under review, with women's voices advocating for improved service delivery. These results were achieved at the backdrop of CSOs shrinking space as the Government continues to institute restrictive measures which make work of civil society organisations difficult. Inconsistent economic policies, lack of fiscal discipline and corruption increased political tensions and on the part of government has contributed to the making the operating environment difficult. The Embassy is in constant dialogue with Diakonia on the effects of these factors on the programme.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Stödet till ”Access to Health Fund” syftar till att öka tillgången till grundläggande hälsotjänster för de mest sårbara människorna i konfliktdrabbade områden.
Två grundläggande prioriteringar för Access to Health Fund är 1) fokus på konfliktdrabbade områden, och 2) fokus på jämlikhet genom ett rättighetsbaserat tillvägagångssätt som främjar icke-diskriminering och uttryckligen riktar sig till de mest sårbara människorna i konfliktdrabbade och svårtillgängliga områden. Access to Health Fund är en givargemensam fond där Schweiz, Storbritannien, USA och Sverige ingår.
Tematiskt ligger fokus på mödra- och barnhälsovård, sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter, nutrition, malaria, tuberkulos, HIV, drogmissbruk, hälsovård i fängelser, infrastruktur samt stärkande av hälsosystemet. Alla insatser kommer att ligga i linje med Myanmars nationella hälsoplan (Myanmar National Health Plan 2017-2021). Den nationella hälsoplanen togs fram med deltagande från alla relevanta aktörer, inklusive etniska hälsoorganisationer.
Geografiskt kommer Access to Health Fund att prioritera insatser i staterna Rakhine, Chin, Kachin, Shan, Kayin, Kayah och Mon, samtliga drabbade av aktiva eller latenta konflikter och alla med mycket låga hälsoindikatorer. Genom att lägga fokus på dessa områden kommer fonden att nå de områden i Myanmar med sämst tillgång till hälsovård, inklusive områden där staten inte har kontroll, samt de mest sårbara grupperna.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The support to Access to Health Fund aims to increase access to quality essential health services for underserved and vulnerable people in conflict-affected areas, and to enable the health system to sustain these gains.
The Access to Health fund builds on two core priorities which are 1) focus on conflict-affected areas, and 2) focus on equity, adopting a human rights based approach to health promoting inclusiveness, and explicitly targeting underserved and vulnerable populations. The Fund is a multi-donor health fund, funded by Switzerland, United Kingdom, USA and Sweden.
The thematic focus areas of the Access to Health Fund will be Maternal, Newborn and Child Health, Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights, Nutrition, Tuberculosis, HIV prevention, Health Consequences of Drug Use, Health in Prisons, Malaria, Infrastructure as well as Health Systems strengthening - all aligned to Myanmar's National Health Plan 2017-2021. The National Health Plan was developed with participation from all key stakeholders, including the health organisations of various ethnic groups.
The Access to Health Fund will concentrate its interventions in Rakhine, Kachin, Shan, Kayin, Kayah and Mon, all states affected by latent or active conflict and all with very low health indicators. The reason behind the Access to Health Fund is prioritizing services in these areas is because access to health services are extremely low. By focusing on these areas, the Fund will be targeting some of Myanmar’s least equitable access-to-health situations and some of the country’s most vulnerable groups, in places that the government often is not able to reach and support.

The objective of Access to Health Fund is to increase access to quality essential health services for underserved and vulnerable people in conflict-affected areas, and to enable the health system to sustain these gains. The foundation of the Access to Health Fund is to focus on conflict-affected areas and to focus on equity. The Access to Health Fund is adopting a rights-based approach promoting inclusiveness, and explicitly targeting underserved and vulnerable populations. This focus on equity defines, to a large extent, the population the Fund will strive to serve. The desired impact of the Access to Health Fund is: - Better overall health status of populations in remote and conflict-affected areas - Reduced health inequalities This will be achieved through focusing activities on 1) increased population access to and use of services (within MNCH, SRHR, Nutrition, Malaria, Tuberculosis, HIV prevention, Health Consequences of Drug Use and Health in Prisons 2) increased collaboration of Government and Ethnic Health Organisations 3) Strengthened Health Systems. The Access to Health Fund will concentrate its interventions in Rakhine, Chin, Kachin, Shan, Kayin, Kayah and Mon, all states affected by latent or active conflict and all with very low health indicators. The reason behind the Access to Health fund is prioritizing services in these areas is because access to health services are extremely low. By focusing on these areas, the Fund will be targeting some of Myanmar’s least equitable access-to-health situations and some of the country’s most vulnerable groups, in places that the government often is not able to reach and support. Universal Health Coverage, the country's goal for 2030, requires access to health for populations throughout the country, and can only be achieved through closer cooperation and coordination with EHOs and their partners as well as ensuring referrals within the overall health system. The recent participation of EHOs in the definition of the National Health Plan, and their explicit responsibility in the delivery of the plan, are indications on the role that these organisations can play. The Fund will continue to promote and support such participation. In the design of the program of the Access to Health Fund, an analysis at the State level, combined with stakeholder consultations (with MoHS, implementing partners, EHOs) has been carried out and will continue. The analysis aims to gage the specific and diverse population needs in program geographies, and to identify appropriate and effective interventions to deliver the outcomes. The program indicators will be revised in line with forthcoming discussions. For the majority of indicators under MNCH, SRHR, and Nutrition, results are based on the national Health Management Information System data as the Fund will be supporting a Township-wide outreach, planning, and commodity supplies to health volunteers. At this stage of the Access to Health Fund, this description is by definition general, lacking the specific indicators and targets that will follow detailed calls for proposals, grant negotiations, and the establishment of defined programs. Examples of indicators for SRHR are Modern Contraceptive Prevalence Rate (MCPR) among married women; Number of young people (aged 10 to 24) reached by SRHR education via interpersonal communication approach; and number of post-abortion care services provided to women through public sector service providers. A result-oriented monitoring and evaluation framework will be finalized after grant negotiations with implementing partners. Considering that the focus on conflict areas have significantly increased as well as the proportion of funds invested in conflict affected townships, it is important to have realistic expectations on health results, and to have a long-term approach. It is not uncommon that when inaccessible areas open up a "backlog" of health needs, long left unattended, is released. Therefore one should expect indicators to get worse before improving.

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Stödet till ”Access to Health Fund” syftar till att öka tillgången till grundläggande hälsotjänster för de mest sårbara människorna i konfliktdrabbade områden.
Två grundläggande prioriteringar för Access to Health Fund är 1) fokus på konfliktdrabbade områden, och 2) fokus på jämlikhet genom ett rättighetsbaserat tillvägagångssätt som främjar icke-diskriminering och uttryckligen riktar sig till de mest sårbara människorna i konfliktdrabbade och svårtillgängliga områden. Access to Health Fund är en givargemensam fond där Schweiz, Storbritannien, USA och Sverige ingår.
Tematiskt ligger fokus på mödra- och barnhälsovård, sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter, nutrition, malaria, tuberkulos, HIV, drogmissbruk, hälsovård i fängelser, infrastruktur samt stärkande av hälsosystemet. Alla insatser kommer att ligga i linje med Myanmars nationella hälsoplan (Myanmar National Health Plan 2017-2021). Den nationella hälsoplanen togs fram med deltagande från alla relevanta aktörer, inklusive etniska hälsoorganisationer.
Geografiskt kommer Access to Health Fund att prioritera insatser i staterna Rakhine, Chin, Kachin, Shan, Kayin, Kayah och Mon, samtliga drabbade av aktiva eller latenta konflikter och alla med mycket låga hälsoindikatorer. Genom att lägga fokus på dessa områden kommer fonden att nå de områden i Myanmar med sämst tillgång till hälsovård, inklusive områden där staten inte har kontroll, samt de mest sårbara grupperna.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The support to Access to Health Fund aims to increase access to quality essential health services for underserved and vulnerable people in conflict-affected areas, and to enable the health system to sustain these gains.
The Access to Health fund builds on two core priorities which are 1) focus on conflict-affected areas, and 2) focus on equity, adopting a human rights based approach to health promoting inclusiveness, and explicitly targeting underserved and vulnerable populations. The Fund is a multi-donor health fund, funded by Switzerland, United Kingdom, USA and Sweden.
The thematic focus areas of the Access to Health Fund will be Maternal, Newborn and Child Health, Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights, Nutrition, Tuberculosis, HIV prevention, Health Consequences of Drug Use, Health in Prisons, Malaria, Infrastructure as well as Health Systems strengthening - all aligned to Myanmar's National Health Plan 2017-2021. The National Health Plan was developed with participation from all key stakeholders, including the health organisations of various ethnic groups.
The Access to Health Fund will concentrate its interventions in Rakhine, Kachin, Shan, Kayin, Kayah and Mon, all states affected by latent or active conflict and all with very low health indicators. The reason behind the Access to Health Fund is prioritizing services in these areas is because access to health services are extremely low. By focusing on these areas, the Fund will be targeting some of Myanmar’s least equitable access-to-health situations and some of the country’s most vulnerable groups, in places that the government often is not able to reach and support.

The objective of Access to Health Fund is to increase access to quality essential health services for underserved and vulnerable people in conflict-affected areas, and to enable the health system to sustain these gains. The foundation of the Access to Health Fund is to focus on conflict-affected areas and to focus on equity. The Access to Health Fund is adopting a rights-based approach promoting inclusiveness, and explicitly targeting underserved and vulnerable populations. This focus on equity defines, to a large extent, the population the Fund will strive to serve. The desired impact of the Access to Health Fund is: - Better overall health status of populations in remote and conflict-affected areas - Reduced health inequalities This will be achieved through focusing activities on 1) increased population access to and use of services (within MNCH, SRHR, Nutrition, Malaria, Tuberculosis, HIV prevention, Health Consequences of Drug Use and Health in Prisons 2) increased collaboration of Government and Ethnic Health Organisations 3) Strengthened Health Systems. The Access to Health Fund will concentrate its interventions in Rakhine, Chin, Kachin, Shan, Kayin, Kayah and Mon, all states affected by latent or active conflict and all with very low health indicators. The reason behind the Access to Health fund is prioritizing services in these areas is because access to health services are extremely low. By focusing on these areas, the Fund will be targeting some of Myanmar’s least equitable access-to-health situations and some of the country’s most vulnerable groups, in places that the government often is not able to reach and support. The recent participation of EHOs in the definition of the National Health Plan, and their explicit responsibility in the delivery of the plan, are indications on the role that these organisations can play. The Fund will continue to promote and support such participation. In the design of the program of the Access to Health Fund, an analysis at the State level, combined with stakeholder consultations (with MoHS, implementing partners, EHOs) has been carried out and will continue. The analysis aims to gage the specific and diverse population needs in program geographies, and to identify appropriate and effective interventions to deliver the outcomes. The program indicators will be revised in line with forthcoming discussions. For the majority of indicators under MNCH, SRHR, and Nutrition, results are based on the national Health Management Information System data as the Fund will be supporting a Township-wide outreach, planning, and commodity supplies to health volunteers. At this stage of the Access to Health Fund, this description is by definition general, lacking the specific indicators and targets that will follow detailed calls for proposals, grant negotiations, and the establishment of defined programs. Examples of indicators for SRHR are Modern Contraceptive Prevalence Rate (MCPR) among married women; Number of young people (aged 10 to 24) reached by SRHR education via interpersonal communication approach; and number of post-abortion care services provided to women through public sector service providers. A result-oriented monitoring and evaluation framework will be finalized after grant negotiations with implementing partners. title.narrative: COVID-19 NPA 2018: basic services, civil society in Syria
COVID-19 NPA 2018: grundläggande samhällstjänster, civilsamhälle i Syrien

description.narrative: Det långsiktiga målet för insatsen är en ökad möjlighet för människor att påverka beslutsprocesser i sina lokalsamhällen. Att stödja syriska civilsamhällsorganisationer samt öka deras förmåga att organisera och mobilisera människor å ena sidan, och å andra sidan påverka lokala samhällsstyrningsstrukturer och makthavare är avgörande för att öka människors deltagande i sina lokalsamhällen. NPA identifierar följande tre förändringar som nödvändiga för att stärka människors inflytande över lokalt beslutsfattande, vilka därför utgör programmets tre huvudsakliga resultatområden: (1) syriska civila samhällsorganisationer påverkar lokala beslutsprocesser (2) Människor har större tillgång till lokala maktinnehavare och styrningsstrukturer, och (3) Lokala maktinnehavare och styrelseformer svarar bättre på medborgarnas behov NPA identifierar fyra huvudsakliga lokala samhällsstyrningsstrukturer: kommunal lokal förvaltning i regimkontrollerade områden; kommuner i oppositionskontrollerade områden; försoningskommittéer eller andra liknande samhällsstyrningsstrukturer i områden under försonings- eller vapenviloavtal; samt självstyre- och lokal förvaltning i områden kontrollerade av PYD. Dessa överlappar dessutom med andra makthavare, såsom beväpnade grupper, stammar, familjer och inflytelserika affärsmän och näringsidkare. Inom alla de styrande strukturer som beskrivs bedömmer NPA människors förmåga att påverka beslutsfattandet som svagt. Det är avgörande för att stärka lokala samhällsstyrningsstrukturers interaktion med människor, stärka människors tillgång till dessa strukturer och att möjliggöra syrianiska CSOs som representerar människors intressen, att rikta sig till lokala maktinnehavare. För att de syriska CSO:erna bättre ska kunna påverka lokala beslutsfattande anser NPA att partners måste bygga sina organisationer med inriktning på både demokratisk intern praxis, förmåga att mobilisera i samhället och bygga allianser. Om syriska partners utvecklas som mer demokratiska och starkare organisationer, kommer de bättre att kunna organisera och representera människor på lokal nivå, eftersom detta ökar deras trovärdighet och representativitet. Detta inkluderar bättre representationer av kvinnor, minoriteter och ungdomar. NPA anser vidare att sådana organisationer som kan identifiera gemensamma intressen och agendor baserade på demokratiska fundament och respekt för mänskliga rättigheter har en bättre grund för alliansbyggande. Sådana allianser skulle i sin tur göra organisationerna till starkare förespråkare för människors intressen gentemot de lokala maktinnehavarna, och ibland även på regional, nationell eller internationell nivå när detta skulle vara relevant för deras orsak.På grund av historiskt ansträngda förhållandet mellan människor och samhällsstyrningsstruktur i Syrien bedömmer också NPA att folk är ovilliga att involvera sig i beslutsprocesser. Det är möjligt att CSOs i detta program strävar efter att samla beslutsfattare och andra intressenter för att förbättra responsen och ansvaret i sina lokalsamhällen. CSO kan spela en viktig roll för att främja och underlätta kommunikationen mellan makthavare och lokalbefolkningen i de olika områdena. CSO:er kommer att spela en viktig roll för att kartlägga behov och möjligheter i lokalsamhällen i syfte att informera beslutsfattare och lokala styrningsstrukturer. Denna process kommer att åtföljas av initiativ från CSOs för att öka medvetenheten om människor i lokalbefolkningen, om politisk kultur och samhällsengagemang. Detta kommer även att främja vikten av samexistens, acceptans för andras åsikter och kvinnors, ungdomars och minoritets roll i beslutsprocesserna.

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Norsk Folkehjelp (NPA) har ansökt om medel för genomförande av programmet "Civil Society and People’s Participation in Syria 2018-2020". Det övergripande målet är att stärka det civila samhället och stödja upprättandet av processer och metoder för att förbättra kvaliteten och omfattningen av människors inflytande på beslutsfattande på lokal nivå. Ett tydligt fokus kommer ligga på att stärka syriska partners kapacitet och förmåga att påverka lokalsamfund. Förändringsteorin fokuserar på kapacitet, attityder, beteenden och att relationer mellan relevanta aktörer förändras: människor, syriska civilsamhällspartners, lokala styrningsstrukturer och andra ansvariga makthavare i samhällena. Programmet genomförs av Norsk folkhjälp (Norwegian People's Aid, NPA) under perioden 2018-2020. Sida stödjer programmet med 54.700.000 SEK.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Norwegian People's Aid (NPA) has applied for a grant for the implementation of the Civil Society and People's Participation in Syria 2018-2020 program. The overall objective is to strengthen civil society and support the establishment of processes and methods to improve the quality and extent of people's influence on decision-making in local government. The approach is based on a grassrot perspective. A clear focus will be on strengthening Syrian partners' capacities and capacity to influence communities. Change theory focuses on capacity, attitudes, behavior and relationships between relevant actors: people, Syrian civil society partners, local governance structures and other powerholders in society. The program is conducted by Norwegian People's Aid (NPA) during the period 2018-2020. Sida supports the program by 54,700,000 SEK.

tag.narrative: 16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.

description.narrative: The project “Civil Society and People’s Participation in Syria” (from now CSPPS) is implemented by NPA between June 2018 – December 2021. This Conclusion on performance covers the period June 2019 - July 2020. The project is implemented in North-East, North-West, and Central Areas of Syria through eight local partners. The Embassy of Sweden in Beirut (EoS) considers that the partners activities are appropriate to reach the planned project outcomes that are outlined as follow: 1: Syrian Civil Society Organizations influence local decision-making processes, 2: People have greater access to local power holders and local governance structures and 3: Community leaders and local governance structures respond better to citizens’ local needs. Capacity building is also a project objective and large part of the activities and of the funding is used for that purpose. NPA started the intervention using a base line research carried out during 2018 which has proven to be an effective method to identify areas of intervention, possible partners, capacities and needs, as well as funding possibilities. It is possible to state that the first achieved result was the obtained capacity to settle partnership with local civil society organization in a complex conflict environment. NPA has reported several results during the period that can be summarized as follow:-Regarding the capacity of partners and the Syrian civil society organizations possibility to influence local decision-making processes: NPA assesses that conducted trainings have helped partners to better coordinate their efforts and promote joint advocacy activities. The creation of an online Northeast NGOs Platform and the coordinated response of the civil society in response to the Turkish military operation in North East Syria in October 2019 are examples of the improved coordination capacity. Partners succeeded in forming alliances and coordinated with other civil society organizations. It is specially highlighted the work of the partner organization ERIDU that managed to include minorities in the coordination efforts.-Regarding greater access to local power holders and local governance structures by the civil society it is highlighted that the partners organizations have managed to bring local community leaders and governance bodies together, opening spaces for dialogue and building trust to improve engagement with the population. NPA has witnessed a change in attitudes, behavior, and relations between civil society organization partners on one hand, and between partners and other local actors on the other hand. Furthermore, NPA inform that more than 20 local development committees and youth networks have been formed with partners support during 2019 in North-West Syria. The committees are working to increase the level of conflict awareness and are supporting local level peace dialogue.-Regarding needs response by Community leaders and local governance structures it is reported that partners are advancing in advocacy and dialogue. It is quoted as example the work of the local partner ASO that supported actors in North-East Syria to participate in the Syria Constitutional Committee process through advocacy towards self-administration and a Kurdish National Council (KNC). -In terms of Capacity development outcomes, NPA has provided the partner organizations swith regular training and mentorship on financial, procurement, human resources and project management, as well as on monitoring and evaluation methods. The result of this process will be externally evaluated in July 2020. NPA has also organised coordination activities to provide local partners with a common arena for dialogue. Those meeting resulted in an improved communication among partners, joint context analyses and coordination to provide inputs for the Geneva process. Until July 2020 an approximately amount of SEK 25 000 000 has been implemented. Furthermore, during the reported period there were two major crises; the Turkish military operation in October 2019 in some areas of implementation and the Covid-19 pandemic. It is assessed by EoS that NPA did a swift adaptation of the implementation capacity during these crises and managed to continue implementing the project. There were a good level of communication and dialogue with and NPA during these both crises. The EoS has visited NPA offices in Beirut twice during the year and one biannual meeting with the organization was held in January 2020. Due to the Turkish military operation in October the planned participation in the partner organization in Erbil in North-East Syria annual meeting was cancelled. Another visit was planned for May 2020, but again cancelled and this time due to Covid-19. The EoS has done followed up on project developments through online meetings and dialogue with the organization as no physical visits have been possible.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Community Security and Stabilization Programme Sudan 2018-2020
COVID-19 Community Security and Stabilization Programme Sudan 2018-2020

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 UNDPs landkontor i Sudan har ansökt hos Sida om finansiering för sitt program "Community Security and Stabilization Programme (C2SP) in Sudan, 2015-2020". Överipande målsättning med programmet är att bidra till stabilitet och ökad motståndskraft i 93 byar i fem stater i södra Sudan; South Kordofan, Blue Nile, West Kordofan, White Nile and North Kordofan. Byarna har valts ut på basis av multidimensionell fattigdom, utsatthet och risk för konflikt, hög arbetslöshet (särskilt bland ungdomar och kvinnor), och för att dessa lokalsamhällen tar emot stora grupper av internflyktingar, flyktingar och migranter. Små ekonomiska möjligheter och resursbrist har lämnat dessa byar särskilt utsatta vilket ökar risken för konflikter av olika slag. Programmet avser bidra till ökade försörjningsmöjligheter och stärkt socio-ekonomisk motståndskraft genom att nå bl.a. arbetslösa ungdomar, flyktingar/migranter och utsatta kvinnor med insatser i de utvalda byarna.
Programmets budget är 17 MUSD. Givare inkluderar Japan, Italien, UK och Spainen. Programmet har nyligen påbörjat en andra fas 2018-2020 under vilken 9,300 personer förväntas nås direkt och 279,000 personer indirekt av insatserna i valda byar och lokalsamhällen. Sida planerar ett stöd till programmet på 45 MSEK 2018-2020.
Programmets målsättningar är:
1) Stärka motståndskraften hos arbetslösa ungdomar som annars löper risken att radikaliseras och mobiliseras i Sudans konflikter, bl.a. genom stöd till ökade försörjningsmöjligheter.
2) Stödja stabilitet och fredsbyggande genom ökad motståndskraft i de lokalsamhällen som tar emot flyktingar och migranter från Sydsudan och internflyktingar pga konflikt, bl.a. genom uppbyggnad av socio-ekonomisk infrastruktur.
3) Stärka lokalsamhällen, staters men även den nationella nivåns kapacitet och förmåga till fredsbyggande och forsatt engagemang i fredsinitiativ, positiv transformering av ungas engagemang, nätverkande, dilaog och lärande.
Programaktiviteter fokuseras till 1) alternativa försörjningsmöjligheter för arbetslösa ungdomar inom tex jordbruk, yrkesutbildningar m.m. 2) ersättningsinvesteringar av basal infrastruktur som t.ex. vattenpumpar i samhällen drabbade av konflikt, 3) stärkt motståndskraft och socialt kapital 4) kapacitetsuppbyggnad av s.k. Community Management Committees (CMCs) och lokal offentlig verksamhet, startbidrag för lokal företagsverksamhet, samarbete med den privata sektorn och finansiella institutioner, korttidsarbeten m.m.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 UNDP country office in Sudan has approached Sida for funding of its Community Security and Stabilization Programme (C2SP) in Sudan which runs between 2015-2020. The overall objective of the programme is to contribute to the stability and resilience of 93 communities in the five states South Kordofan, Blue Nile, West Kordofan, White Nile and North Kordofan. The targeted communities were selected on the basis of a multidimensional poverty and conflict exposure analysis conducted by UNDP and are characterized by being on the verge of conflict, suffering from high unemployment rates (particularly among women and youths) and/or hosting large groups of IDPs/refugees/migrants. Limited economic opportunities and resource scarcity has further exacerbated development challenges in many of these communities and are likely to contribute to distress and conflicts in the near future if left unaddressed. The programme aims at building inclusive livelihoods and strengthen socio-economic resilience of the targeted communities by addressing the specific needs of e.g. unemployed youth, displaced population and women at risk.
The programme budget is US$ 17,066,000. Other donors include Japan, Italy, UK and Spain. The programme has recently (January 2018) entered into its second phase during which it is planning to reach a minimum of 9,300 direct and 279,000 indirect beneficiaries in the prioritized communities. Sida is considering a support of approx. 45 000 000 SEK during 2018-2020.
The specific objectives of the programme are:
1) To strengthen the resilience of unemployed youth who have the potential to be radicalized and mobilized to join conflicts by the provision of livelihood support and generation of the rural economy in the southern States bordering South Sudan
2) To promote stability and peace-building by strengthening the resilience of communities hosting refugees and migrants from South Sudan and IDPs resulting from internal conflict by providing socio-economic infrastructure and assets to benefit all.
3) To enhance the capacity of peacebuilding structures at the community, state, and national levels to continue promoting and engaging in peace initiatives, positive transformation of youth, networking and provide space for dialogue and learning.
Programme activities focus on 1) providing alternative livelihoods for unemployed youth through, e.g., farming activities, vocational skills training, workshops and awareness raising; 2) replacement of basic infrastructure (e.g. water pumps) in conflict-ridden communities; 3) strengthening of community resilience and social cohesion; 4) capacity development of Community Management Committees (CMCs) and local government entities. Start-up support for local businesses, facilitation of linkages with the private sector and financial institutions, creation of short-term jobs and support to community-based initiatives will also form part of the comprehensive programme.

The UNDP Community Security and Stabilization Programme (C2SP) intends to contribute to the stability and resilience of the selected vulnerable communities, which are at the risk of being drawn into conflicts in six states of Sudan; South Kordofan, Blue Nile, West Kordofan, White Nile, Sennar and North Kordofan. It aims to achieve this by: (i) Strengthening resilience of target communities through provision of diversified alternative livelihoods for at-risk groups primarily focussing on unemployed youth who are at risk of being drawn into conflicts, refugees, IDPs, returnees and at-risk women, (ii) Creating a conducive environment for graduated small arms control at the sub regional, national and community level to reduce the occurrence of armed conflicts and loss of life, (iii) Provision of socio-economic infrastructure in targeted communities having direct relevance to the conflicts, (iv) Strengthening the communities to manage the community infrastructure and NGO/CBO service providers for improved service delivery to target beneficiaries and communities for long term peace and stability, (v) Promoting cross-border cooperation among the communities and authorities for enhancing stability at the bordering communities.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

tag.narrative: 1.5 - By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.

1.5 - Till 2030 bygga upp motståndskraften hos de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer och minska deras utsatthet och sårbarhet för extrema klimatrelaterade händelser och andra ekonomiska, sociala och miljömässiga chocker och katastrofer.
16.1 - Avsevärt minska alla former av våld och dödligt våld överallt.
16.1 - Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.
16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.

description.narrative: Between January 2019 and December 2019, C2SP supported 13 communities across states (White Nile, Blue Nile, North Kordofan, West Kordofan and South Kordofan), assisting a total of 29.250 beneficiaries (50% women) with the additional Sida funding. In total, the C2SP has reached 41 communities since its inception in 2015 (including the 13 Sida funded communities). Under Output 1, providing alternative livelihood support to at-risk/unemployed youth, a total 1600 households were assisted during the reporting period. Activities included training on soap making, provision of festival equipment for women, and the establishment of show clubs for youth, grinding mills. Under Output 2, relating to the provision of socio-economic infrastructure, assets or basic facilities in support of economic recovery and conflict mitigation established, C2SP assisted all 13 targeted communities with infrastructure and/or assets such as tractors, harvesters, trailers and wide level discs with a total of 23 assets. The equipment is owned by the community and is managed by a Community Management Committee (CMC), which arealso established by the C2SP (a total of 13 were established with Sida funding in 2019). Under Output 3, dealing with peacebuilding and reconciliation, 12 peacebuilding sub-committees (to the CMCs) were established with Sida funding. The committees are trained in reconciliation and conflict management, and succeeded in resolving a total of 21 different disputes in 2019. Under Output 4, strengthening the capacity of government and local service providers, a total of 3 government institutions, 13 NGOs have been provided technical assistance and trainings. During the 2019 implementation period, C2SP faced a number of significant challenges. The biggest challenge was the civil unrest/revolution, which both affected the movement of staff and caused major disruptions in the government's operations. The cash and fuel shortages also proved difficult and caused delays in the operations.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Community Security and Stabilization Programme Sudan 2018-2020
COVID-19 Community Security and Stabilization Programme Sudan 2018-2020

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 UNDPs landkontor i Sudan har ansökt hos Sida om finansiering för sitt program "Community Security and Stabilization Programme (C2SP) in Sudan, 2015-2020". Överipande målsättning med programmet är att bidra till stabilitet och ökad motståndskraft i 93 byar i fem stater i södra Sudan; South Kordofan, Blue Nile, West Kordofan, White Nile and North Kordofan. Byarna har valts ut på basis av multidimensionell fattigdom, utsatthet och risk för konflikt, hög arbetslöshet (särskilt bland ungdomar och kvinnor), och för att dessa lokalsamhällen tar emot stora grupper av internflyktingar, flyktingar och migranter. Små ekonomiska möjligheter och resursbrist har lämnat dessa byar särskilt utsatta vilket ökar risken för konflikter av olika slag. Programmet avser bidra till ökade försörjningsmöjligheter och stärkt socio-ekonomisk motståndskraft genom att nå bl.a. arbetslösa ungdomar, flyktingar/migranter och utsatta kvinnor med insatser i de utvalda byarna.
Programmets budget är 17 MUSD. Givare inkluderar Japan, Italien, UK och Spainen. Programmet har nyligen påbörjat en andra fas 2018-2020 under vilken 9,300 personer förväntas nås direkt och 279,000 personer indirekt av insatserna i valda byar och lokalsamhällen. Sida planerar ett stöd till programmet på 45 MSEK 2018-2020.
Programmets målsättningar är:
1) Stärka motståndskraften hos arbetslösa ungdomar som annars löper risken att radikaliseras och mobiliseras i Sudans konflikter, bl.a. genom stöd till ökade försörjningsmöjligheter.
2) Stödja stabilitet och fredsbyggande genom ökad motståndskraft i de lokalsamhällen som tar emot flyktingar och migranter från Sydsudan och internflyktingar pga konflikt, bl.a. genom uppbyggnad av socio-ekonomisk infrastruktur.
3) Stärka lokalsamhällen, staters men även den nationella nivåns kapacitet och förmåga till fredsbyggande och forsatt engagemang i fredsinitiativ, positiv transformering av ungas engagemang, nätverkande, dilaog och lärande.
Programaktiviteter fokuseras till 1) alternativa försörjningsmöjligheter för arbetslösa ungdomar inom tex jordbruk, yrkesutbildningar m.m. 2) ersättningsinvesteringar av basal infrastruktur som t.ex. vattenpumpar i samhällen drabbade av konflikt, 3) stärkt motståndskraft och socialt kapital 4) kapacitetsuppbyggnad av s.k. Community Management Committees (CMCs) och lokal offentlig verksamhet, startbidrag för lokal företagsverksamhet, samarbete med den privata sektorn och finansiella institutioner, korttidsarbeten m.m.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 UNDP country office in Sudan has approached Sida for funding of its Community Security and Stabilization Programme (C2SP) in Sudan which runs between 2015-2020. The overall objective of the programme is to contribute to the stability and resilience of 93 communities in the five states South Kordofan, Blue Nile, West Kordofan, White Nile and North Kordofan. The targeted communities were selected on the basis of a multidimensional poverty and conflict exposure analysis conducted by UNDP and are characterized by being on the verge of conflict, suffering from high unemployment rates (particularly among women and youths) and/or hosting large groups of IDPs/refugees/migrants. Limited economic opportunities and resource scarcity has further exacerbated development challenges in many of these communities and are likely to contribute to distress and conflicts in the near future if left unaddressed. The programme aims at building inclusive livelihoods and strengthen socio-economic resilience of the targeted communities by addressing the specific needs of e.g. unemployed youth, displaced population and women at risk.
The programme budget is US$ 17,066,000. Other donors include Japan, Italy, UK and Spain. The programme has recently (January 2018) entered into its second phase during which it is planning to reach a minimum of 9,300 direct and 279,000 indirect beneficiaries in the prioritized communities. Sida is considering a support of approx. 45 000 000 SEK during 2018-2020.
The specific objectives of the programme are:
1) To strengthen the resilience of unemployed youth who have the potential to be radicalized and mobilized to join conflicts by the provision of livelihood support and generation of the rural economy in the southern States bordering South Sudan
2) To promote stability and peace-building by strengthening the resilience of communities hosting refugees and migrants from South Sudan and IDPs resulting from internal conflict by providing socio-economic infrastructure and assets to benefit all.
3) To enhance the capacity of peacebuilding structures at the community, state, and national levels to continue promoting and engaging in peace initiatives, positive transformation of youth, networking and provide space for dialogue and learning.
Programme activities focus on 1) providing alternative livelihoods for unemployed youth through, e.g., farming activities, vocational skills training, workshops and awareness raising; 2) replacement of basic infrastructure (e.g. water pumps) in conflict-ridden communities; 3) strengthening of community resilience and social cohesion; 4) capacity development of Community Management Committees (CMCs) and local government entities. Start-up support for local businesses, facilitation of linkages with the private sector and financial institutions, creation of short-term jobs and support to community-based initiatives will also form part of the comprehensive programme.

The UNDP Community Security and Stabilization Programme (C2SP) intends to contribute to the stability and resilience of the selected vulnerable communities, which are at the risk of being drawn into conflicts in six states of Sudan; South Kordofan, Blue Nile, West Kordofan, White Nile, Sennar and North Kordofan. It aims to achieve this by: (i) Strengthening resilience of target communities through provision of diversified alternative livelihoods for at-risk groups primarily focussing on unemployed youth who are at risk of being drawn into conflicts, refugees, IDPs, returnees and at-risk women, (ii) Creating a conducive environment for graduated small arms control at the sub regional, national and community level to reduce the occurrence of armed conflicts and loss of life, (iii) Provision of socio-economic infrastructure in targeted communities having direct relevance to the conflicts, (iv) Strengthening the communities to manage the community infrastructure and NGO/CBO service providers for improved service delivery to target beneficiaries and communities for long term peace and stability, (v) Promoting cross-border cooperation among the communities and authorities for enhancing stability at the bordering communities.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 SWEFOR:s skyddsprogram syftar till att bidra till en miljö där människorättsförsvarare kan stärka sin kapacitet och på ett effektivt sätt genomföra betydelsefulla åtgärder för deras inverkan på Colombias demokratiska utveckling och hållbara fred. I övergången från kontexten av väpnad konflikt spelar civilsamhället och människorättsförsvarare en nyckelroll för att säkerställa att konfliktens slut också leder till ett mer motståndskraftigt samhälle som kan lösa konflikter på icke-våldsamma sätt. I den meningen är det avgörande att människorättsförsvarare kan arbeta i en fredlig miljö. Programmet får 24 230 368 SEK mellan åren 2017-2021.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 SweFOR’s protection program aims to contribute to an environment where human rights defenders can strengthen their capacities and can properly implement self-care measures for their impact on Colombia’s democratic development and sustainable peace. In the transition from a context of armed conflict, civil society and human rights defenders play a key role to ensure that the end of hostilities also lead to a more resilient society that can resolve conflicts through non-violent ways. In this sense, it is critical that human rights defenders can work in a hostility-free environment. The program will receive 24 230 368 SEK between 2017-2021.

Through this project, SweFOR will help strengthen the protection of human rights defenders and social leaders and expand their scope of action. In this way, they will be able to demand greater guarantees in the defense of their rights.

title.narrative: Amendment 3 to the Grant Agreement between Sida and SweFOR
Grant Agreement between Sida and SweFOR
Beslut om ändring av insats Kristna Fredsrörelsen (SweFOR)

description.narrative: During 2020, SweFOR and the Embassy maintained very close dialogue with regards to its adaptation to the COVID-19 situation. It is SweFOR’s assessment that there were several unexpected results in 2020. On March 1, 2020 SweFOR received new peace observers, and roughly 20 days later, the whole country was placed on lockdown. This proved to be a challenging situation for them, as they were required to remain in lockdown within the SweFOR house with new colleagues, and with little support available. Despite this complex scenario, only 2 observers out of the entire group decided to return to Sweden and all international staff have extended their contract for an additional year. This is testament to SweFOR’s hard work in improving the work culture and work environment. Sida welcomes this type of initiatives to make staying more attractive, as the high turnover rate and its associated costs, was a concern for years. Similarly, SweFOR has demonstrated it is adept at managing COVID cases. 2 observers have been infected; however, they have been successfully isolated without further incidence in the observer team. New recruitments have been done virtually and have worked surprisingly well as well. By the last week of January, SweFOR is expecting 4 new observers from Sweden. The COVID-19 pandemic meant that the majority of the work during 2020 was done virtually (March to August). Mid-August, SweFOR became one of the first international organizations to go back to the field, this time, to support the Corporación Claretiana Norman Pérez Bello (CCNPB) in Guayabero, Meta. SweFOR signed two new agreements with Colombian human rights organizations in 2020, Sisma Mujer and Movice Bogotá Chapter. The work with Sisma Mujer has been very positive, because they have been able to accompany them in virtual hearings. It has been more challenging to work with MOVICE due to the more traditional/older profile of their members and the type of work they carry out. Overall, SweFOR thinks it is hard to establish new relationships with these organizations virtually, but is proud of the work they have carried out thus far. In general, connectivity has been an issue with some organizations and has been a challenge for SweFOR and its ability to carry out its work. This is especially critical due to the fact that the very nature of SweFOR’s work is that it is carried out in- person. Despite that, the balance is more positive than expected. Some outcomes for 2020 are the following: - 140 accompaniments planned/146 carried out (some “rondas” or check-ins were done virtually). - 146 days in the field vs. 124 in 2019. This is because of the prolonged presence SweFOR observers had in Guayabero Meta, with CCNPB. - 65 accompanied persons vs. 55 in 2019. This number has gone up because of the mutual need to meet between accompanied person or organization and SweFOR. There are less scheduling conflicts when the accompaniment can be done online, thus leading to higher numbers in this respect. Although positive that it remained in touch with APOs, SweFOR still mourns the loss of in-person relationship building. SweFOR is still analyzing the impact of this new work modality, but quantitatively, it is happy with these preliminary results. In terms of political accompaniment, SweFOR was surprised at the level of positive response from Authorities during the COVID-19 pandemic. They received more answers to their communications and outreach efforts than usual. The same was not the case for the international community, as many focal points were sent back to their places of origin, thus making lobbying at the international level in Colombia more challenging. All political incidence tours were held virtually except for one in-person mission to Chocó. Similarly, all self-protection workshops were held virtually, 28 in total. The number of participants was much higher than usual, however, SweFOR is critical as to claiming it as a success due to people logging in and out. It will work towards finding a way to measure impact in this regard. Some noteworthy accompaniments of 2020: SweFOR provided accompaniment to Yirleidy Velasco, to whom Sisma Mujer provides legal support. SweFOR wrote a letter of concern to the Inter-American Commission for Human Rights and Ms. Velasco was awarded cautionary measures. As a result, SweFOR considers its political impact positively in this case. SweFOR provided almost permanent accompaniment to the social leaders of CCNPB in the Espacio Humanitario in Guayabero, Meta from August to December. This was done as an exception because there were no other requests due to the Pandemic. Leyner Palacios (one of the few individuals to receive personalized accompaniment) was a target of threats during early 2020. As a result, he was relocated to Cali, from Bojayá, Chocó. SweFOR observers lived with him for a number of weeks and thanks to the Embassy’s support, psychosocial support was provided to him and his family until the end of 2020. SweFOR continues to check in on him periodically now that he was named a Commissioner in the Truth Commission. SweFOR nominated Leyner for the Defender of the Year award in Diakonia’s annual Human Rights Prize, which he won.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Makedonien har åtagit sig att arbeta för en stärkt jämställdhet genom dels internationella åtaganden och dels nationella policies och planer. I Makedonien har en reform av den offentliga finansiella styrningen inletts där man bl.a vill införa programbaserad budgetering. Man önskar även införliva en jämställdhetsintegrerad budgetprocess. Det betyder att nationella och lokala budgetar formuleras, planeras, genomförs och utvärderas med hänsyn till de olika behov män, kvinnor, pojkar och flickor har samt vilka effekter som budgeten ger för dessa olika grupper. Reformen berör både central och kommunal nivå. UN Women har sedan tidigare arbetat med jämställdhetsintegrering i budgetprocesser, i Makedonien och i ett 70-tal andra länder. I föreliggande programförslag i Makedonien medverkar, förutom berörda stats- och kommuntjänstemän, även parlamentariker och kommunpolitiker samt civilsamhällesorganisationer. Sida, tillsammans med schweiziska SDC, stödjer detta arbete under perioden 2018-2021 med ett belopp om totalt 11,7 miljoner SEK.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Macedonia has made commitments to work for improved gender equality by signing international conventions and enacting national laws and policies. An ongoing reform of the public financial management system includes an initative to introduce and institutionalise gender responsive budgeting (GRB). This means that national and local budgets are formulated, planned, executed and evaluated with consideration to the needs of men, women, boys and girls, and that the effects budgets bring are analysed with reference ot these groups. The reform concerns both central and municipal level. UN Women has been involved in GRB work both in Macedonia and in around 70 other countries in the world. The programme in Macedonia involves civil servants both at central and local level, parliamentarians, local politicians and civil society organisations. Sida, together with Swiss SDC, supports the implementation of the programme with 11.7 million SEK during the period 2018-2021.

The project Promoting Gender Responsive Policies and Budgets: Towards Transparent, Inclusive and Accountable Governance in FYR of Macedonia has an overall objective “To improve women’s lives and support the inclusion of the most vulnerable groups through systematic and sustainable integration of gender perspective at all stages of national and local policy-making and budgeting processes.” To contribute to the achievement of the overall goal, the project will work towards achieving the following two outcomes: - The Government’s public finance management and the strategic planning processes are improved to respond to the different needs of women and men as a result of effective application of gender responsive budgeting - Civil society organizations, women, including the most vulnerable actively participate in planning and decision-making mechanisms, and their priorities are fully reflected in public policies and budgets. The theory of change of the proposed intervention is as follows: IF (1) national and local institutions formulate, implement and monitor evidence-based policies and budgets which fully reflect gender equality commitments; (2) Members of Parliament and gender advocates demand accountability to GEWE commitments; (3) Women, including the most vulnerable, voice their needs and participate in local planning and decision-making; THEN more women, including the most vulnerable, will influence the development of and benefit from gender responsive policies and budgets; BECAUSE the capacities of national and local institutions are increased, accountability mechanisms are strenghtened and women's needs and concerns are fully taken into consideration.

title.narrative: Agreement Promoting Gender Responsive Policies and Budgets - Towards Transparent inclusive and Accountable Governance in FYR Macedonia 12372
Decision on Contribution Promoting Gender Responsive Policies and Budgets - Towards Transparent inclusive and Accountable Governance in FYR Macedonia 12372

description.narrative: The EC progress report for North Macedonia for 2020 reports on “some progress made” on equality between women and men. Despite the legal framework which is largely in line with the EU acquis, there is still a need for upgrading following the ratification of the Istanbul Convention. North Macedonia published its first Gender Equality Index in October 2019, which indicated improvements regarding equality in decision making. Nevertheless, the gender gap in this field is assessed to be significant. Gender stereotyping persists, and attacks to women are noted. Women in public life are susceptible to particularly vicious attacks through social media, which was confirmed during the parliamentary elections in 2020. Systematic data gathering on gender-based violence is lacking. The action plan for the Istanbul Convention lacks specific funding for its effective implementation. UN Women maintains its role as strategic partner to the Ministry of Labour and Social Policy, and it provides direct support to the capacity development of the institution. Besides the challenges and restrictions imposed due to Covid 19 pandemics, UN Women reports on important progress achieved under the project Promoting Gender Responsive Policies and Budgets: Towards Transparent, Inclusive and Accountable Governance in North Macedonia. At central level the project is reporting on the following results: - Finalized evaluation of the progress and impact of the National Strategy for Gender Equality (2013- 2020) and the National Action Plan on Gender Equality (2018-2020), and providing important recommendations and baseline data for conceptualizing the strategic goals for advancing gender equality in the upcoming 5 years. Initiation of development of the new National Strategy for Gender Equality (2021-2026) by the means of established Working Group composed of representatives of Government institutions, local government, and civil society. Provided support to the Ministry of Labour and Social Policy in drafting documentation of best practices on GRB in the region, to be used as resource document in guiding and mentoring other line-ministries in adopting and implementing similar practices on GRB in North Macedonia. Organized series of workshops for line-ministries and state agencies for applying gender responsive budgeting in the development of the strategic plans, programmes, and budgets for the upcoming year. Developed sector-specific briefs for each institution and discussed gender responsive interventions in alignment with the gender equality commitments set in the Government Work Plan (2020 – 2024). All recommendations for gender responsive measures are reported as shared by the Ministry of Labour and Social Policy to the relevant line-ministries for their integration in the new 3-annual strategic plans. Prepared Guidelines for gender mainstreaming in the strategic plans of line ministries/state institutions in alignment with the gender specific provisions in the Government Strategic Planning Methodology, providing important information and tools for public administration to apply GRB. Provided recommendations to Ministry of finance in introducing gender in several important Articles of the Final draft of the new Organic Budget law (Article 3 – Budgetary Principles, Article 8 – Fiscal and other implications when proposing acts and regulations, Article 31 – Proposed financial plans of budget users, Article 92 – Content of the Annual Budget Execution Report of the state or the municipality). On the basis of the recommendations of the Working Group on COVID-19, the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy adopted a new Rulebook related to production and sale of food of non-animal origin, with new criteria which are more responsive to the needs of women small scale producers. Provided expert support by UN Women in mainstreaming gender in the new Strategy for Regional Development of the Republic of North Macedonia (2020 – 2029) including recommendations for 12 sectoral studies that are incorporated in the Strategy. On mainstreaming gender in the oversight role of the Parliament, the Members of Parliament and representatives from the Parliamentary Institute are introduced to the application of gender-responsive budgeting in the review and oversight of the proposed legislation, policies and budgets. The capacity strengthening of the Parliamentary Institute on gender responsive legislative and policy review resulted with Comparative Analysis from gender perspective on financing of political parties in North Macedonia developed by the Parliamentary Institute. At local level UN Women provided: Mentoring support to the municipalities by a local team of experts - focused on data collection and consultation with Coordinators on equal opportunities for adapting local programmes and budgets to the newly emerged situation caused by COVID-19. Support to municipality of Skopje to finalize its Strategy on Gender Equality for the period 2020-2025, as well as an Action Plan containing measures and activities to be implemented by the end of 2025. Support to municipality of Stip to develop a new Strategy on Gender Equality, which is in a final phase of adoption, Support to municipalities Aerodrom and Bitola, with mentoring support from UN Women, in conducting gender analysis upon which new Strategies on Gender Equality will be developed. On cooperation with associations of local authorities UN Women supported: Implementation of the first e-learning course by the Network of Associations of Local Authorities (NALAS) on Gender Mainstreaming and GRB in Macedonian, Albanian and Turkish language(http://nalas.eu/News/e-Academyautumn) . Compiled through NALAS network of Knowledge Management Assistants and shared best practices on Gender Responsive budgeting at Local Level across the countries of South East Europe. Updated and developed e-platform with new tools for collecting gender disaggregated data from all municipalities by ZELS. Access to the platform is enabled for each municipality in North Macedonia, allowing them to insert and update regular gender disaggregated data and information about their municipality. Regarding the cooperation with the local CSO sector UN women reports on: Selection of Akcija Zdruzenska and the National Council for Gender Equality, in partnership with AGORA as Responsible parties to implement outreach and empowerment initiatives for increased participation of women in local decision-making processes. The CSOs are covering eight administrative planning regions in the country in order to ensure full geographical reach. Activities in response to Covid-19 pandemic The mapping study on the impact of Covid-19 on the socio-economic situation of women at local level was promoted at the online workshop for sharing best practices in the area of innovation of social services. A total of 32 representatives from 26 municipalities participated at the workshop, discussing on how to address the gendered impact of Covid-19 at local level based on the mapping study and sharing gender responsive initiatives that were undertaken during the Covid-19 crisis. The Rapid Gender Assessment (RGA) of Covid-19 was published on both English and Macedonian (https://bit.ly/3lvElOs). The RGA is expected to serve as data source to support policymaking initiatives to address the gendered impact from the pandemic, to identify the key priorities to support the most vulnerable groups and to understand different dimensions of how affected women and men experience and cope with the outbreak. In addition, findings of the RGA serves as a basis in the development of the strategic plans of the line-ministries and for the situational analysis for the new National Strategy for Gender Equality (2021-2026). Rapid assessments were initiated in five municipalities Strumica, Kochani, Veles, Gjorce Petrov and Sveti Nikole in engendering the selected local programmes and budgets to better respond to the post-emergency needs due to Covid-19. The assessments are to be finalized in the first quarter of 2021. Regarding communication of project results: Public awareness raising campaign has been completed under the title "Why Your Money Counts? The goal of the campaign was to improve understanding that public funds influence the lives of women and men differently, and to raise awareness how all citizens, women and men, can demand accountability and transparency of public spending. The related social media posts during the campaign are reported to have a reach-out to over 15,000 people and had over 2,500 organic engagements. Unexpected negative results The imposed Covid-19 protecting measures and restrictions to in-person meetings resulted with cancellation of travels and organizing trainings on-line. This had an underspending effect to the project budget. The underspending of project budget has been discussed by the Embassy with UN Women and an early alert to the possibility of requesting six-months no-cost extension to the project (extending the project end date to 1st April 2023) has been mentioned. Due to Covid-19 pandemic and changing political decision-makers after the elections, the slow processes and decision-making by the Ministry of Labour and Social Policy in finalizing the process of adaptation of the operating space for the Center of Excellence on GRB. It is expected that the premises for the Center of Excellence will be fully functional by the first quarter of 2021 and depending on the Government crisis measures in response to Covid-19 the official launch of the center will be decided.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Bygga kapacitet för projektgenomförande på lokal nivå (UNDP)
COVID-19 UNDP BMCPI - Buidling Municipal Capacity for Project Implementation

description.narrative: New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Together with local institutions in Macedonia, UNDP will build municipal capacity for planning and preparing for infrastructure investments in line with requirements of investment financiers while taking various relevant aspects into account (f.ex. environment and climate, gender and regional balance). In this way, also resource-poor municipalities can access available investment finance. The project that Sida supports aims at, 1. establising a Municipal Development Index, where indicators objectively show municipalities' level of development in various areas, 2. conducting a functional analysis of local governance in Macedonia, to identify structural inefficiencies and recommend changes, 3. establishing a Technical Documentation Fund, that will assist resource-poor municipalities undertake necessary preparations for local infrastructure investments.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Tillsammans med lokala institutioner i Makedonien kommer UNDP att bygga och stärka kommuners kapacitet att planera och förbereda för infrastrukturinvesteringar på ett sätt som följer de krav investeringsfinansiärer har och som tar relevanta aspekter i beaktande (t.ex. miljö och klimat, jämställdet och regional balans). På så vis kan tillgång till tillgängliga investeringsmedel nås även för mindre kommuner med lägre kapacitet. Projektet som Sida stödjer ämnar att, 1. inrätta ett kommunalt utvecklingsindex, där indikatorer visar olika kommuners utvecklingsnivå inom olika områden 2. genomföra en funktionsanalys av lokalförvaltningen i Makedonien för att identifiera ineffektiva strukturer och rekommendera ändringar, 3. inrätta en fond för stöd till förberedelser, ffa teknisk dokumentation, i syfte att bistå resurssvaga kommuner med nödvändiga förberedelser inför lokala infrastrukturinvesteringar.

The problems that the project seeks to address constitute three key difficulties in capitalizing on local development opportunities; i) lack of reliable and comparable municipal level development data, ii) ill-equipped and inadequately structured municipal administrations, failing to effectively plan, design and implement development policies and optimise available scarce funding; iii) inability of municipal administrations to make use of available donor/national investment funding, due to deficient preparatory work. The response will focus on the following three complementary activities/outputs: 1) Create a Municipal Sustainable Development Index in partnership with the Ministry of Local Self-Government and the Association of LSGUs (ZELS), allowing for an objective and comparative view on development progress in all municipalities. 2) Carry out a simple functional analysis of the local governance system, focusing on the ability to deliver development progress at local level, and proposing realistic structural changes that should be piloted in entities expressing interest to do so. 3) Establish a Technical Documentation Fund, which would provide resources to less-developed municipalities for undertaking long-term investment projects. Support should be provided during the whole investment cycle (planning, prioritization, application, implementation). The theory of change for the Project is formulated as: Better informed local/national institutions will be better equipped to create realistic and relevant evidence-based local development policies and plan expenditures, especially on local infrastructure. Improved technical capacity of municipalities and better coordination between relevant institutions will be prompted by initial funding and development of technical documentation and progress in data collection and dissemination of information leading to municipalities that are better prepared to use structural funds from funding institutions and effectively satisfy their community needs. The UNDAF outcome that the project contributes to is: "By 2020, national and local institutions are better able to design and deliver high-quality services for all users, in a transparent, cost-effective, non-discriminatory and gender-sensitive manner." The project can contribute to improving the quality of life for local inhabitants and to improve the country's readiness for EU membership.

title.narrative: Cost sharing agreement for building municipal capacity for project implementation SIDA UNDP
Cost sharing agreement AMENDMENT for building municipal capacity for project implementation SIDA UNDP
020545-20 Beslut om ändring av insats, MK bygga kapacitet för projektgenomförande på lokal
Beslut om insats, Bygga kapacitet för projektgenomförande på lokal nivå (UNDP)

description.narrative: During the period, the project has achieved good progress 1) The Municipal Sustainable Development Index is reported to be at a final stage of preparation, and related report is expected by the end of February. The Municipal Sustainable Development Index includes gender sensitive indicators. The Index is developed in partnership with the Ministry of Local Self-Government and the Association of LSGUs (ZELS). The local ownership and practical use of this product should be reconfirmed through the regular project monitoring . 2) The functional analysis of the local governance system, is partly elaborated and is put on hold until the post-election period. Continued work on the functional analyses is preconditioned with the strategic position of the new Government related to the decentralisation proces and local development plan. Depending on the above the realistic structural changes can be proposed, that should be piloted in local entities which will express interest to do so. 3) The Technical Documentation Fund is established and put in function. The first call for municipal authorities to apply for support has been published, and 36 project proposals (out of received 68 applications) were selected for preparation of technical documentation. Compliance with the SDG's and gender mainstreamed applications were part of the selection criteria.

title.narrative: SKL - kapacitetsutveckling av lokala guvernorat i Irak (LOGDEVI) 2018-2021
SKL/SALAR Local Governance Development in Iraq (LOGDEVI) 2018-2021

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 SKL har inkommit med en projektansökan till Sida om en budget på 67 300 000 SEK för att implementera "Local Governance Development in Iraq (LOGDEVI)" i Irak, 2018-2021.
Projektet syftar till att bidra till Iraks decentraliseringsreform och förbättring av sociala tjänster i tre guvernorater, Duhok, Diwaniyah och Muthanna med två följande mål: 1) Upprätta politiska ramverk, system och processer som bidrar till effektiv decentralisering i Muthanna och Diwaniyah. Guvernoraterna strävar även efter att fungera som modell för övriga Irak och 2) Integrerad styrning för förbättrad service och barnskydd i Iraks Kurdistan.
SKL kommer att implementera projektet tillsammmans med en lokal organisation, Iraqi Research Foundation for Analysis and Development (IRFAD).

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The project proposal "Local Governance Development in Iraq (LOGDEVI)", 2018-2021 submitted by SALAR has a requested budget of 67 300 000 SEK.
The project aims to contribute to Iraq's decentralisation reform and improving social services in three guvernorates, Duhok, Diwaniyah and Muthanna with the following objectives: 1) Policy framework, systems, and processes are established which are conducive for effective decentralisation in Muthanna and Diwaniyah - and serve as a model for the rest of Iraq och 2) Integrated governance for improved service delivery and child protection in Kurdistan region of Iraq. To implement this project, SALAR will collaborate with a local organisation, Iraqi Research Foundation for Analysis and Development (IRFAD).

The proposed intervention by SALAR is expected to strengthen local governance and service delivery to become more effective, people-centred, and accountable in three governorates in Iraq including the Kurdistan area of Iraq.
