title.narrative: Studio Yafa Information and dialogue for social cohesion in Burkina Faso
Studio Yafa "Information och dialog för social sammanhållning i Burkina Faso"

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Fondation Hirondelle, en ideell organisation baserad i Schweiz som arbetar med att stärka oberoende media i framförallt konfliktdrabbade länder, hartill Ambassaden inkommit med en ansökan om stöd till projektet Information och dialog för att stärka den sociala sammanhållningen samt inkluderande och fredligt deltagande i Burkina Faso, under perioden 2019-2021.
Projektet motiveras av de senaste årens omvälvande utveckling i Burkina Faso där en folklig resning 2014 ledde till en demokratisk övergång men också ekonomiska och säkerhetsrelaterade utmaningar, vilket ger starka skäl för Sverige att bidra till en konsolidering av demokratin. Burkina Faso har en mycket ung befolkning, och syftet med insatsen är att ge befolkningen, särskilt de unga, möjlighet att göra sin röst hörd, informera sig och utbyta åsikter samt stimulera dialog, debatt och deltagande i det offentliga livet.
Det övergripande målet med insatsen är att förebygga konflikter, bidra till att stärka fred och social sammanhållning genom information och dialog mellan människor i alla regioner i Burkina Faso. De tre specifika målen är att (1) öka informationen till befolkningen i Burkina Faso, särskilt unga, och göra dem mer aktiva i demokratiska utvecklingsprocesser genom informations- och dialogprogram, (2) stärka och göra den burkinska mediesektorn mer professionell genom utbildning och tekniskt stöd. (3) göra projektet hållbart genom att anta en handlingsplan upprättad av berörda parter.
Strategin är att stärka det burkinska demokratiska systemet och det burkinska samhällsengagemanget, främst hos unga Projektägaren Fondation Hirondelle (FH) ska producera dagliga informationsprogram och multimediadebatter riktade till ungdomar, mestadels flickor och befolkningsgrupper långt ifrån stadskärnor. Det kommer att ske via radioprogram riktade specifikt till dessa områden, både via privata och statliga radioprogram. Journalister från dessa områden samt lokala ungdomsorganisationer (projektpartner) kommer att delta. Projektet är ett försök att förbättra den nationella sociopolitiska situationen. Insatsens budget är 22,8 MSEK varav Sida bidrar med 10 MSEK och Schweiz bidrar med 12,8 MSEK .

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Fondation Hirondelle (FH), a non-profit organisation based in Switzerland working to strengthen independent media in especially conflict-affected countries , has submitted an application for support to the project Studio Yafa/Information and dialogue to strengthen social cohesion and inclusive and peaceful participation in Burkina Faso, for 2019-2021.
The project is motivated by the revolutionary development of recent years in Burkina Faso, where a popular rise in 2014 led to a democratic transition but also economic and security-related challenges, which gives strong reasons for Sweden to contribute to a consolidation of democracy. Burkina Faso has a very young population, and the purpose of the effort is to give the population, especially the young, the opportunity to make their voices heard, inform themselves and exchange views, and stimulate dialogue, debate and participation in public life.
The overall objective of the intervention is to prevent conflicts, contribute strengthen peace and social cohesion through information and dialogue between all peoples and all in all regions of Burkina Faso. The three specific objectives of the intervention are: i) better inform and make more active the population of Burkina Faso, especially young people, in democratic and development processes through information and dialogue programs; ii) strengthen and make the Burkinabé media sector more professional through training and technical support; iii) make the project sustainable by adopting an action plan by the partners involved.
The strategy is to strengthen the Burkinabé democratic system and the citizenship of the Burkinabé, mainly the young and the most marginalized. FH will implement a Studio and produce daily information programs and multimedia debates aimed at young people and populations far from urban centers. This production will be done with community and private radios which touch these areas, journalists coming from these areas and youth local organisations (project partners). The thematics will be in line with the country main challenges and the national socio-political situation.

The overall objective is to contribute to strengthen democracy and citizenship of Burkinabè, mainly young people and the most marginalized. It is also prevent conflicts, contribute to strengthening peace and social cohesion through information and dialogue between all peoples and all in all regions of Burkina Faso. The three specific objectives of the intervention are: i) better inform and make more active the population of Burkina Faso, especially young people, in democratic and development processes through information and dialogue programs; ii) strengthen and make the Burkinabé media sector more professional through training and technical support; iii) make the project sustainable by adopting an action plan by the partners involved. The strategy is to enable people to participate more in democratic processes and in the development of Burkina Faso, mainly the young and the most marginalized. FH will set up a radio studio and produce daily information programs and multimedia debates aimed at young people and the rural population. This production will be done with community and private radios which touch these areas, journalists coming from these areas and youth local organisations (project partners). The themes will be in line with the country main challenges and the national socio-political situation. At the end, Burkinabé democratic system and Burkinabé people, mainly young and marginalized will be strengthened through discussions, exchanges, and at the end that peace and social cohesion are established. The Theory of change outlined by the project is that by providing the population with accurate and adequate information, their capacities capacities for dialogue and conflict resolution are strengthened which enables them to participate in democratic processes och contributing to good governance.The rationale behind supporting people's participation in democratic processes is based on the fact that if young people have access to information about the modalities and opportunities for participating in democracy, if they have the knowledge to make better decisions and exercise their rights, then they will engage actively in the construction of public life, social, economic and political development. The rationale behind contributing to good governance and monitor the government's actions is based on the fact that if the Burkinabe population has access to information and exchange programs that allow citizens, experts, opposition and government to express itself, then the actions and decisions of the government will become more transparent to the citizens and this will increase their confidence in their government. The rationale behind strengthening the processes of dialogue and conflict resolution in Burkina Faso by the fact that if the people, the government, the opposition, the experts, the actors in civil society have a healthy space for dialogue, then they understand and will be able to defuse potential conflicts. And if the audience, people perceive that it is possible for groups of conflict prevention to discuss their issues peacefully, then a culture of peace that promotes peaceful conflict resolution will be strengthened. Finally, the project aims to consolidate the media sector, as key to the success of the three previous stages of the theory of change: If Burkina Faso's media sector is strengthened and professionalized thanks to training and technical support, then the Burkinabe media will be better able to assume their mission and in particular to give the floor and respond to the information needs of young people in Burkina Faso.

description.narrative: The Project's ambition was that by the end of the first year, the productions broadcast on radio and television would be accessible to approximately 20% of the Burkinabè population, in all regions of the country. This objective during the 14 months (November 2018-December 2019) of Studio Yafa's implementation is largely achieved. Inded, more than 60% of the urbain and rural population can receive information from Studio Yafa. The young people who listen and follow Studio Yafa's broadcasts in many languages (Dioula, French, Fulfuldé, Gulmencema and Mooré) are aware of the topics covered and that their participation in public debate is increased thanks to the space for dialogue offered during outdoor debates. The majority of its listeners find that the programs are reliable and of quality and the treatment of the subjects of the programs leads the young people to become aware of their well-being. Outcome 1: The Burkinabe population, and especially young people, are better informed and more active in democratic and development processes thanks to information and dialogue programs Unanimously in the various localities, the information from Studio Yafa is considered reliable by the respondents to the focus groups organized by ICI a study firm and to a mini survey carried out in partnership with Viamo, our distribution partner via telephony. Whether in the case of mini-mags or talk shows, the quality of the shows is highly appreciated. A considerable part of those polled also believe that these programs should be the subject of wider distribution and more effective promotion to listeners: “These emissions are very good, because after listening you can decide to change. We want Studio Yafa to advertise more so that we can listen to their work more often. We will take the opportunity to invite our loved ones to listen to the studio's broadcasts. "(Testimony of a woman met in Dédougou during the investigation conducted by ICI, December 2019). Other testimonies, collected by the directors of the partner radio stations from young listeners, indicate that the treatment of the subjects of the programs leads "young people to an awareness for their well-being". Studio Yafa's 15 partner radios (Unalfa) find the programs produced interesting for young people in their community. Finally, a mini survey carried out as part of the partnership with Viamo made it possible to assess the appreciation of Orange telephone subscribers compared to Yafa's mini-mags. 1,450 people answered the questionnaire between April 11 and June 11. The results are positive, with 53% of respondents finding Yafa's magazine great; 27%: very good; 11%: it works and 9%: bad The results of the outcome 1 is achieved throught results from outputs: Output 1: An audio and video production studio which respects professional and ethical journalism rules is created. - One (1) operational local law structure which strictly respects journalistic rules has been created: Studio Yafa- - Studio Yafa's production team is recruited (23 Burkinabè employees, including 14 men and 9 women, on average 33 years old) - An audio and video production studio that respects professional and ethical journalism rules has been created - Studio Yafa is now the only professional audio and video production studio dedicated to young people that respects the professional and ethical rules of journalism, and which works with a network of 25 Burkinabè radio stations across the country Output 2: A greater supply of information that allows the Burkinabè population, especially young people, to understand the important issues in their lives and to be active citizens is proposed. The results of the 1st studies and survey of listeners show that Studio Yafa's information offer is relevant for young people. The topics covered are varied, while taking into account the main concerns of young people, namely employment and social cohesion: - Several media contents have been developed in five languages ??(Dioula, French, Fulfuldé, Gulmencema and Mooré). - 5 daily mini-magazines of 3 min in 5 languages - Between 1 to 2.5 min of video in French, - Daily posts on Facebook and Twitter pages - Daily feed to Studio Yafa's website. Output 3: Media spaces and platforms created for young Burkinabe allow them to make their voices and concerns heard, as well as to dialogue with political leaders and decision-makers The production of media programs and content has contributed to enriching the information offer for young people in the country as well as providing them with spaces for dialogue. - The Studio's broadcasts through the 25 partner radio stations covered 75% of the territory, giving access to information to a majority of Burkinabé. - 33 weekly programs in French of 45 minutes "Ya'Débat" were produced and broadcast. - 31% of women under 35 participated in the "Ya'Débat" - several hundred young Burkinabè participated in 4 outdoor public debates of 45min were organized in Bobo-Dioulasso, Léo and Tenkodogo Output 5: Access to information and dialogue programs via a network of Burkinabè media partners throughout the country and on the web is improved. - Partnership was signed with UNALFA, UBESTV. - 25 partner radios benefit from training and internship at the studio - Studio Yafa covers approximately 75% of the territory, thus giving access to information to a majority of the Burkinabè population. - 50% of listeners follow the Studio's radio programs in the regions. - 12,000 Facebook subscribers under 35, 380 Tweeter followers follow the programs - 500 videos on average per month are viewed on Facebook and 1,000 on Youtube. - Numerous audio programs, articles, photos and videos are posted daily and weekly on the website studioyafa.org - The Studio's audience increased thanks to the successful partnership with Viamo which made it possible to increase the distribution of mini-mags via telephony Outcome 2: The Burkinabè media sector is strengthened and more professional thanks to training and technical support Output 6: The editorial and managerial capacities of partner radio stations are strengthened - 15 journalists (4 women and 11 men aged 33) were trained in good journalistic practices - 4 journalists-trainees of correspondents and benefit from remote coaching - 22 Directors and representatives of 18 radio stations received training on revenue generation and monetization of digital content Output 7: The technical capacities of partner radio stations are strengthened: A kit of reports and a computer given to 15 partner radio stations Output 8: The training offer for Burkinabè students is strengthened: - Two students did an immersion of 2 months each at Studio Yafa. One will write a dissertation on information for young people at Studio Yafa; the other on the impact of radio productions on youth. These dissertations will enrich the studio's impact work in the second half of 2020. - Training for 20 young high school students in 1st and Terminal to introduce them to the basics of radio journalism (in collaboration with Goethe Institue)
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: Rädda Barnen utbildning i konflikt Afghanistan, 2018-2021
Save the Children Education in Emergencies Afghanistan, 2018-2020

description.narrative:
Denna insats syftar till att erbjuda utbildning och stöd till återvändande, internflyktingar, barn med funktionshinder samt andra utsatta grupper i tre provinser.
Programmets övergripande mål är att öka tillgången till inkluderande utbildning av god kvalitet och att skapa en säker lärandemiljö för de pojkar och flickor i åldern 5-15 år som drabbats av konflikter och katastrofer. Projektet beräknas erbjuda 7 600 barn (50% flickor) grundskoleutbildning (årskurs 1 till 3) och 5 600 barn (50% flickor) en ettårig förskoleutbildning.
Projektets prioriterade verksamhetsområden är följande: (1) utbildning av flickor, internflyktingar, återvändande barn samt barn i utsatta samhällen; (2) stödja registrering och inkludering av barn i det formella skolsystemet; (3) utöka alternativa utbildningsformer (Community Based Education) och utbildning i konfliktområden; och (4) skapa skydd för utsatta barn samt bidra till ökad tillgång på vatten och sanitetsanrättningar i anslutning till skolan.
Denna insats är högst relevant utifrån den svenska strategin för utvecklingssamarbete med Afghanistan 2014-2019 avseende tillgång till förbättrad skolgång för flickor och pojkar och gör det möjligt för fler flickor och pojkar att slutföra sin skolgång. Insatsen bidrar också till ökad respekt för de mänskliga rättigheterna, med särskild inriktning på barnens möjligheter att åtnjuta sina mänskliga rättigheter samt strategiresultatet att förstärka kapaciteten inom offentliga institutioner när det gäller tillhandahållande av grundläggande samhällstjänster.
Save the Children International Afghanistan (SCI-A) är den främsta implementeraren av programmet och kommer att arbeta tillsammans med en lokal partner, Welfare Association for the Development of Afghanistan (WADAN). Rädda Barnen Sverige är Sidas avtalspartner avseende denna insats.
Sida bidrar med 24 MSEK för genomförandet av projektet under perioden från december 2018 till maj 2020.

The proposed intervention aims to provide integrated community-based education and child protection services for returnees, Internally Displace Persons, vulnerable host communities, and children with disabilities in three provinces.
The overall objective of the programme is to improve the access to inclusive quality education in emergencies, and provide a safe learning environment for conflict affected boys and girls aged from 5 to 15 years old in three provinces. The intervention will target 7,600 children (50% girls) within primary education (grade 1 to grade 3) and 5,600 children (50% girls) within a one-year community-based pre-school education in the three considered geographical areas.
The priority areas of the project are: (1) focus on education of girls, vulnerable Host Communities (HC), Internally Displaced People (IDP) and returnee children; (2) support enrolment of HC, IDP and returnee children into formal schools; and (3) expand Community Based Education (CBE) and Education in Emergency (EiE) Classes; (4) Child Protection and WASH services.
This intervention is highly relevant according to the Results strategy for Sweden’s international development cooperation with Afghanistan, 2014–2019 regarding access to improved schooling for girls and boys and making it possible for more girls and boys to complete their schooling. It is also related to results on strengthened respect for human rights, with particular focus on the opportunities of children to enjoy their human rights, and the result on strengthened capacity of public institutions to provide basic services in Afghanistan.
Save the Children International Afghanistan (SCI-A) is the main implementer of the pogramme and will work with a local partner, Welfare Association for the Development of Afghanistan (WADAN). Save the Children Sweden is Sida's contract partner for this contribution.
Sida supports the intervention by providing 24 MSEK for the implementation of the project during the period from December 2018 to May 2020.

The proposed project aims to provide integrated community-based education and child protection services for returnees (documented and undocumented), Internally Displaced Persons (conflict and natural disaster affected), vulnerable host communities, and children with disabilities in Kabul, Balkh and Jawzjan Provinces. The overall objective of the programme is to improve the access to quality and inclusive education in emergencies, and provide a safe learning environment for conflict affected girls and boys aged from 5 to 15 years in three provinces. The total number of people targeted through this intervention is more than 43,000 (29,000 girls and boys and 14,000 women and men, i.e. teachers, parents, community members and others). The expected results are as follows: 1. Increased access to quality basic education for Internally Displaced Persons (IDP), returnee and host community boys and girls. 2. A child-friendly, protective and inclusive environment is created for emergency-affected boys and girls. 3. Continuity of Education for emergency-affected girls and boys is increased. 4. Quality of learning for emergency-affected girls and boys is improved. A robust child protection component is integrated into the intervention, supporting children to overcome their trauma, reintegrate into the community and return to normalcy. A Logical Framework has been developed as an annex to the proposal. Some of the stated outputs are as follows: Enhancing capacity of School Management Committees/Shuras and School Councils to seek community support for the enrollment of boys and girls in Community Based Education (CBE)/Education in Emergencies (EiE) classes; provision of teaching and learning kits; access to gender friendly wash facilities; establishment of Child Friendly Spaces where CBE classes have been established; provision of psychosocial trainings along with the delivery of psychosocial first aid; and providing supplies to and training of hub-school teachers on child friendly gender sensitive and inclusive teaching methodologies. Adjustment PHASE II and Corona Outbreak By the time of the COVID 19 outbreak, Save the Children was fairly much in phase with the planned activities. However, the Corona virus has definitely changed the methods, means and challenges working in Afghanistan in many ways. If this situation will remain during 2021 or not, is hard to assess. Nevertheless, the long term consequences of the COVID 19 will have long terms effects on the country. Although there are a number of technical or methodological changes taken to combat the problems causued by the Pandemia, the four expected results are still as valid as previously. Consequently the Since the schools have been closed for a period, Save the Children and other actors have developed methods to provide education by Internet, TV and Radio instead of cancelled classes. Teachers are given teacher training kits to support them by self-learning and the provision of Water and Sanitation facilities in schools are to be increased as this also is a measure to minize the effects of the Corona Pandemia. Due to the Covid Pandemia there is an improved cooperation between the MoE, Save the Children and the member organizations of the EiE working group - being a result that could facilitate the development of the Afghanistan Education system in a long-term perspective.As for the new long distance means developed to provide learning kits, education by radio and other methods developed currently, would provide better alternatives for presumptive pupils in Emergency or conflict areas even in the future.

tag.narrative: 4.1 - By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
4.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla flickor och pojkar fullbordar avgiftsfri och likvärdig grundskole- och gymnasieutbildning av god kvalitet som leder till relevanta och ändamålsenliga kunskaper.

4.5 - By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.

4.5 - Senast 2030 avskaffa skillnaderna mellan könen inom utbildningsområdet och säkerställa lika tillgång till utbildning och yrkesutbildning på alla nivåer för utsatta personer, inklusive personer med funktionsnedsättning, ursprungsfolk och barn som lever under utsatta förhållanden.

4.7 - By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and non-violence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture’s contribution to sustainable development.

4.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla studerande får de kunskaper och färdigheter som behövs för att främja en hållbar utveckling, bland annat genom utbildning för hållbar utveckling och hållbara livsstilar, mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet, främjande av en kultur av fred, icke-våld och globalt medborgarskap samt värdesättande av kulturell mångfald och kulturens bidrag till hållbar utveckling.

description.narrative: During the first 13th month period, Save the Children Sweden (SCS), Save the Children International-Afghanistan (SCI-A) and Partner WADAN managed to start up all the pre-planned activities in line with plan, although in some cases a bit later than anticipated. During this period: - Project staff and Community Mobilizers have been recruited and the project has been introduced to Provincial Education Departments and District Education Departments in Kabul, Balkh and Jawzjan provinces. - 218 Community Based Education (CBE) teachers have been recruited and provided with trainings on modern teaching methodologies as well as on psychosocial support (PSS). - 218 CBE classes, 94 preschool classes and 66 Child Friendly Spaces (CFS) have been established. - Approximately 7,600 children (including more than 4 000 girls) have completed grade 1 while pre-school children will be transitioned into grade 1 in the beginning of 2020. More than 1,000 children participated in the Child Friendly Spaces (CFS) and will in the upcoming cycle be transferred to Community Based Education. In certain areas there are no formal education buildings for the enrollment of children to grade 1, thus classes will take place in community buildings or homes. In 2020, due to national Covid-19 restrictions, face-to-face activities in Afghanistan were suspended from March to September 2020. This meant that several planned activities were postponed, altered, or cancelled. To ensure continued project implementation, SCS worked with the Ministry of Education (MoE) to refine its strategy and developed alternative learning pathways, including the following modalities: 1) home based self-learning program; 2) distance learning program through television and radio; and 3) reduced sizing of classes (i.e. 6-8 students per class), along with increased hygiene and disinfection standard operating procedures. Until September 2020: - 95% of 7,671 students (4,361 girls and 3,310 boys) have been benefitted through home-based learning modality. - Remote case identification and referral mechanism was established and practiced during the pandemic. Project staff were regularly contacting teachers and community education councils and asking them about student’s health status and child protection risks associated to children especially child labor. A total of 222 cases (106 boys and 116 girls) have been referred so far. - SCI-A is providing education to 80 children with hearing and visual impairment under the Joyful Learning project.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
